Award.AwardTitle: Supports for Science and Mathematics Learning in Pre-Kindergarten Dual Language Learners: Designing a Professional Development System

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is a collaborative effort of the National Institute for Early Education Research (NIEER) at Rutgers University, Perth Amboy Public Schools, Elizabeth Public Schools, Long Branch Public Schools, and Open Minds, LLC with the overarching goal of improving the readiness of dual language learners (DLL) for kindergarten. Based on research indicating that very young learners can accomplish more than we have expected of them and that inquiry-based science programs and literacy programs are mutually supportive, especially for English language learners, the project is designing, implementing, and studying the effects of workshops for 48 teachers of 3 and 4 year-olds in three urban school districts.

The project will monitor the extent to which teachers adopt and implement recommended instructional approaches and the impacts of the professional development experience on their attitudes and knowledge. The data will provide preliminary answers to three questions about the professional development model: 1) Does the PD experience enhance teacher knowledge and classroom interactions around mathematics and science? 2) Does it enhance classroom supports for dual language learners? and 3) Does the PD experience produce results confirming that math and science experiences can contribute to, rather than detract from, language development and literacy learning for all students?

The key outcomes of the project will be insights into the effects of integrated mathematics, science, and literacy instruction for very young children and, potentially a model for teacher professional development that encourages such content integration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Young children’s abilities, knowledge, and skills in math and science just after preschool predict how they will do in adolescence in math and science...and also in reading! Many young children in the United States who are members of groups at risk for lack of school readiness – e.g., dual language learners (DLLs) – often start preschool behind their peers in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and then stay behind. High quality early educational experiences can help, but many early childhood educators do not feel well-prepared to teach STEM. Our project, SciMath-DLL, was born to address this gap. We aimed to increase preschool teachers’ skills, abilities, and confidence in teaching STEM to all children, including DLLs. We believe this will lead to greater learning for all children. The two main goals of the SciMath-DLL project were to: 1) develop and refine an innovative preschool professional development model to support STEM instruction for all children, including dual language learners (DLLs), and 2) to collect evidence of its effectiveness.

 

The SciMath-DLL model was built on current best-practice thinking in early STEM teaching and learning and early childhood professional development by experts in early STEM learning, teaching, and development along with educators and school district leaders. During the first year of this 4-year study, we designed the three-pronged approach to supporting teachers. The first prong is creating district-wide or multi-district hands-on workshops. The second is establishing professional learning communities (PLCs) or workgroups in which teachers within centers support each other’s STEM practice, facilitated by coaches. The third is conducting individualized reflective coaching cycles (RCCs), which are co-coached by STEM experts.  Our model evolved over the course of the next two years as we co-developed the model with a group of educators working in public schools. Teachers and master teachers told us what was working and what was not, and we improved our model. We made changes based on their feedback, for example, we included model lesson plans and increased opportunities for active learning in workshops. Hearing from educators and incorporating their ideas was a critical component of success. In the final year, we used our refined model with a new group of teachers. By the end of our 4-year study, our model produced overwhelmingly positive feedback from educators.

 

The intellectual merit of our project is grounded in the power of STEM education to improve language with older DLLs and in the power of programs with a single content focus (e.g., math) to produce gains for children in STEM and in language. Our study provided teachers with the tools to provide rich STEM experiences for their children, and also gave them strategies to implement lessons and engage DLLs in scientific and mathematical thinking. Our results suggest that a long-term, intensive, multi-pronged approach to in-service professional development can positively influence teachers, master teachers, and children. Our qualitative analyses from this study found evidence that teachers felt more confident in their STEM teaching, master teachers and researchers noticed improvements in teachers’ teaching quality, and teachers reported positive effects on child learning. One effect that the research team and master teachers observed was teachers streamlining lessons. Early in the study, many teachers were “overstuffing” lessons so that the learning objectives were not clear. One master teacher noted, "I am absolutely amazed by the impact the SciMath-DLL project has had on our teachers...teachers are putting more and more thought into their lesson planning as well as setting specific goals and objectives for their students."
